title: Master of Computer Applications (MCA) Scheme of Teaching and Evaluation (STE)

content.title: Vision
description: To nurture creative thinkers who will drive positive global change

content.title: Mission
description: To offer multi, inter and cross-disciplinary modular programmes with technology-enabled
teaching-learning processes.
To focus on research-led teaching and learning in an innovative and interdisciplinary learning
environment; to create critical thinkers.
To create leaders for a knowledge based economy, with ethical demands of a society base.
To engage talented intellectual capital with strong faculty diversity in knowledge and experience.
To ensure transformation of learning into positive behaviour of students.

sections.title: Vision and Mission

content.title: Vision
description: To provide professional education integrated with globally relevant technology.

content.title: Mission
description: To motivate students to pursue a quality-driven lifelong learning and continuing education by
providing an educational experience, well grounded in mathematical and scientific principles as
well as fundamental concepts and theories of computer science.
To adapt academic activities to meet the ever-changing needs of society and industry.
To recognize and encourage excellence in academics and research.
STE 2023-25 School of Science Studies
Master of Computer Applications

sections.title: First Semester Syllabus
content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Summarize the concepts of data structures and their applications.
CO2: Analyze and represent data using various data structures like hash tables, trees and graphs to solve
CO3: Choose and design an appropriate data structure for a specified problem.
CO4: Develop and analyze algorithms for data structure operations.
CO5: Apply the concepts of data structures in solving real-world problems.

objectives: 1. To strengthen the ability to identify and apply the suitable data structure for the given real world
2. To develop skills to analyze and design of hash tables and priority queues.
3. To be able to design and analyze the various tree data structures.
4. To be able to design and analyze the various graph data structures.
5. To enable them to write algorithms for solving problems with the help of fundamental data

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: INTRODUCTION TO DATA STRUCTURES
9 Hours
Review of basic data structures- Abstract data types, Data Structures, Algorithms, Big Oh, Small Oh,
Omega and Theta notations, Solving recurrence relations, Master theorems.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: HASHING AND PRIORITY QUEUES
9 Hours
Review of Hashing, Hash Function, Collision Resolution Techniques in Hashing, Separate Chaining,
Open Addressing, Linear Probing, Quadratic Probing, Double Hashing, Rehashing, Extendible
Hashing, Priority Queues, Definition, ADT, Realizing a Priority Queue using Heaps, Definition,
Insertion, Deletion.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: TREES
9 Hours
Review of trees, Binary search trees, Balanced search trees, AVL trees, Splay trees, Red-black trees,
B-trees, B+ trees, Tries.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: GRAPHS
9 Hours
Graph ADT, Graph Representations, Graph Traversals, Depth First Search, Breadth First Search,
Topological Sort, Shortest Paths, Dijkstra’s Algorithm, Minimum Spanning Tree, Prim’s Algorithm,
Kruskal’s Algorithm.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: ALGORITHM DESIGN TECHNIQUES
9 Hours
Greedy Algorithms, Divide and Conquer, Dynamic Programming, Backtracking, Branch and Bound.

textbooks: 1. Mark Allen Weiss, “Data Structures and Algorithm Analysis in C++”, 4th Edition, Pearson
2. A. V. Aho, J. E. Hopcroft, and J. D. Ullman, “Data Structures and Algorithms”, Pearson
references: 1. T. H. Cormen, C. E. Leiserson, R. L. Rivest, and C. Stein, “Introduction to Algorithms”, 3rd
2. S. Sahni, “Data Structures, Algorithms and Applications in C++”, 2nd Edition, University Press,
3. R. Lafore, “Data Structures and Algorithms in Java”, 2nd Edition, Sams Publishing, 2003.
laboratory: 1. Write a C program to implement hashing with separate chaining.
2. Write a C program to implement hashing with open addressing.
3. Write a C program to implement a priority queue using a heap.
4. Write a C program to implement an AVL tree.
5. Write a C program to implement a splay tree.
6. Write a C program to implement a red-black tree.
7. Write a C program to implement a B-tree.
8. Write a C program to implement a B+ tree.
9. Write a C program to implement a trie.
10. Write a C program to implement Dijkstra’s algorithm.
11. Write a C program to implement Prim’s algorithm.
12. Write a C program to implement Kruskal’s algorithm.

content.name: Advanced Data Structures using C and Lab
content.prerequisites: Basic Programming, Data Structures CIE Marks 50

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the concepts of relational and non-relational databases.
CO2: Apply the concepts of query processing and optimization.
CO3: Apply the concepts of transaction management, concurrency control and recovery.
CO4: Understand the concepts of distributed databases and NoSQL databases.
CO5: Understand the concepts of data warehousing and data mining.

objectives: 1. To understand the concepts of relational and non-relational databases.
2. To learn the concepts of query processing and optimization.
3. To understand the concepts of transaction management, concurrency control and recovery.
4. To learn the concepts of distributed databases and NoSQL databases.
5. To understand the concepts of data warehousing and data mining.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: RELATIONAL DATABASES
9 Hours
Introduction to Relational Model, SQL, Normalization, Query Processing and Optimization, Transaction
Processing, Concurrency Control, Recovery.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: PARALLEL AND DISTRIBUTED DATABASES
9 Hours
Database System Architectures: Centralized and Client-Server Architectures, Server System
Architectures, Parallel Systems, Distributed Systems, Parallel Databases: I/O Parallelism, Inter and Intra
Query Parallelism, Inter and Intra operation Parallelism, Design of Parallel Systems, Distributed
Database Concepts, Distributed Data Storage, Distributed Transactions, Commit Protocols, Concurrency
Control in Distributed Databases, Availability, Query Processing in Distributed Databases.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: OBJECT AND OBJECT RELATIONAL DATABASES
9 Hours
Concepts for Object Databases: Object Identity, Object structure, Type Constructors, Encapsulation of
Operations, Methods, and Persistence, Type and Class Hierarchies, Inheritance, Complex Objects,
Object Database Standards, Languages and Design: ODMG Model, ODL, OQL, Object Relational and
Extended – Relational Systems: Object Relational features in SQL/Oracle, Case Studies.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: EMERGING DATABASE TECHNOLOGIES
9 Hours
XML Databases: XML Data Model, DTD, XML Schema, XML Querying, Web Databases, Geographic
Information Systems, Biological Data Management, Cloud Based Databases: Data Storage Systems on
the Cloud, Cloud Storage Architectures, Cloud Data Models, Query Languages, Indexing in Cloud
Databases, Case Studies.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: NOSQL DATABASES
9 Hours
NoSQL Databases: Introduction, CAP Theorem, Document Based, Key-Value Stores, Column Based,
Graph Based, NoSQL MongoDB, Cassandra, HBASE, Neo4j, NoSQL vs SQL.

textbooks: 1. R. Elmasri and S. B. Navathe, “Fundamentals of Database Systems”, 7th Edition, Pearson
2. A. Silberschatz, H. F. Korth, and S. Sudarshan, “Database System Concepts”, 7th Edition,
references: 1. C. J. Date, A. Kannan, and S. Swamynathan, “An Introduction to Database Systems”, 8th
2. P. J. Sadalage and M. Fowler, “NoSQL Distilled: A Brief Guide to the Emerging World of
3. S. Ceri and G. Pelagatti, “Distributed Databases: Principles and Systems”, 1st Edition,
laboratory: 1. Write a SQL query to create a table and insert data.
2. Write a SQL query to update and delete data from a table.
3. Write a SQL query to retrieve data from a table using various clauses.
4. Write a SQL query to perform joins and subqueries.
5. Write a PL/SQL program to create a function and a procedure.
6. Write a PL/SQL program to create a trigger.
7. Write a program to implement a distributed database.
8. Write a program to implement a NoSQL database.
9. Write a program to implement a data warehouse.
10. Write a program to implement a data mining algorithm.

content.name: Advanced Database Management Systems and Lab

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of operating systems.
CO2: Apply the concepts of process management, memory management, and storage management.
CO3: Apply the concepts of protection and security.
CO4: Understand the concepts of distributed systems.
CO5: Understand the concepts of virtualization and cloud computing.

objectives: 1. To understand the basic concepts of operating systems.
2. To learn the concepts of process management, memory management, and storage management.
3. To understand the concepts of protection and security.
4. To learn the concepts of distributed systems.
5. To understand the concepts of virtualization and cloud computing.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: INTRODUCTION
9 Hours
What is an Operating System, Simple Batch Systems, Multiprogrammed Batches systems, Time-Sharing
Systems, Personal-computer systems, Parallel systems, Distributed Systems, Real-Time Systems,
System components, Operating-System services, System calls, System programs, System structure,
Virtual machines.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: PROCESS MANAGEMENT
9 Hours
Process concept, Process scheduling, Cooperating processes, Threads, Interprocess communication,
Scheduling criteria, Scheduling algorithms, Multiple-processor scheduling, Real-time scheduling,
Algorithm evaluation, The Critical-Section problem, Synchronization hardware, Semaphores, Classical
problems of synchronization, Critical regions, Monitors.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: MEMORY MANAGEMENT
9 Hours
Logical and Physical Address Space, Swapping, Contiguous Allocation, Paging, Segmentation,
Segmentation with Paging, Virtual Memory, Demand paging, Page replacement, Page-replacement
algorithms, Performance of demand paging, Thrashing, Demand segmentation.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: STORAGE MANAGEMENT
9 Hours
File concept, Access methods, Directory structure, File-system mounting, File sharing, Protection, File-
system structure, Allocation methods, Free-space management, Directory implementation, Efficiency
and performance, Recovery, Log-structured file systems, NFS.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: PROTECTION AND SECURITY
9 Hours
Goals of protection, Domain of protection, Access matrix, Implementation of access matrix,
Revocation of access rights, Capability-Based systems, Language-Based Protection, The Security
problem, Authentication, One-Time passwords, Program threats, System threats, Threat monitoring,
Encryption, Computer-Security classifications.

textbooks: 1. A. Silberschatz, P. B. Galvin, and G. Gagne, “Operating System Concepts”, 10th Edition,
references: 1. W. Stallings, “Operating Systems: Internals and Design Principles”, 9th Edition, Pearson, 2018.
2. A. S. Tanenbaum, “Modern Operating Systems”, 4th Edition, Pearson, 2015.

content.name: Operating System
content.prerequisites: Computer Organization and Architecture CIE Marks 50

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of probability and statistics.
CO2: Apply the concepts of probability distributions, sampling distributions, and estimation.
CO3: Apply the concepts of hypothesis testing, correlation, and regression.
CO4: Understand the concepts of analysis of variance and design of experiments.
CO5: Understand the concepts of statistical quality control.

objectives: 1. To understand the basic concepts of probability and statistics.
2. To learn the concepts of probability distributions, sampling distributions, and estimation.
3. To understand the concepts of hypothesis testing, correlation, and regression.
4. To learn the concepts of analysis of variance and design of experiments.
5. To understand the concepts of statistical quality control.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: INTRODUCTION TO PROBABILITY
9 Hours
Sample space and events, Axioms of probability, Conditional probability, Bayes’ theorem, Random
variables, Discrete and continuous random variables, Probability distributions, Mathematical expectation.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: PROBABILITY DISTRIBUTIONS
9 Hours
Discrete distributions: Binomial, Poisson, Geometric. Continuous distributions: Uniform, Normal,
Exponential, Gamma. Joint distributions, Marginal and conditional distributions, Covariance and
correlation, Central limit theorem.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: SAMPLING AND ESTIMATION
9 Hours
Sampling distributions, t-distribution, Chi-square distribution, F-distribution, Point estimation,
Interval estimation, Confidence intervals for mean, proportion, and variance.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: HYPOTHESIS TESTING
9 Hours
Null and alternative hypotheses, Type I and Type II errors, Level of significance, One-tailed and two-
tailed tests, Tests for mean, proportion, and variance, Analysis of variance, One-way and two-way
classification.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: CORRELATION AND REGRESSION
9 Hours
Simple linear correlation and regression, Multiple correlation and regression, Coefficient of
determination, Goodness of fit, Non-linear regression.

textbooks: 1. J. L. Devore, “Probability and Statistics for Engineering and the Sciences”, 9th Edition, Cengage
2. R. A. Johnson, I. Miller, and J. Freund, “Miller & Freund’s Probability and Statistics for
references: 1. S. C. Gupta and V. K. Kapoor, “Fundamentals of Mathematical Statistics”, 12th Edition, Sultan
2. R. E. Walpole, R. H. Myers, S. L. Myers, and K. Ye, “Probability & Statistics for Engineers &

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of artificial intelligence.
CO2: Apply the concepts of problem solving, search, and knowledge representation.
CO3: Apply the concepts of planning, learning, and natural language processing.
CO4: Understand the concepts of expert systems and robotics.
CO5: Understand the concepts of machine learning and deep learning.

objectives: 1. To understand the basic concepts of artificial intelligence.
2. To learn the concepts of problem solving, search, and knowledge representation.
3. To understand the concepts of planning, learning, and natural language processing.
4. To learn the concepts of expert systems and robotics.
5. To understand the concepts of machine learning and deep learning.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: INTRODUCTION TO ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
9 Hours
What is AI, The AI Problems, The Underlying Assumption, What is an AI Technique, The Level of the
Model, Criteria for Success, Some General References, One Final Word and Beyond.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: PROBLEM SOLVING
9 Hours
State Space Search, Production Systems, Problem Characteristics, Heuristic Search Techniques, Generate-
and-Test, Hill Climbing, Best-first Search, Problem Reduction, Constraint Satisfaction, Means-ends
Analysis.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: KNOWLEDGE REPRESENTATION
9 Hours
Knowledge Representation Issues, Representations and Mappings, Approaches to Knowledge
Representation, Issues in Knowledge Representation, The Frame Problem, Representing Simple Facts in
Logic, Representing Instance and ISA Relationships, Computable Functions and Predicates, Resolution,
Natural Deduction.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: PLANNING AND LEARNING
9 Hours
Planning, The Blocks World, Components of a Planning System, Goal Stack Planning, Nonlinear
Planning, Hierarchical Planning, Reactive Systems, Learning, Rote Learning, Learning by Taking Advice,
Learning in Problem-solving, Learning from Examples: Induction, Explanation-based Learning, Discovery,
Analogy, Formal Learning Theory, Neural Net Learning and Genetic Learning.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: NATURAL LANGUAGE PROCESSING AND EXPERT SYSTEMS
9 Hours
Natural Language Processing, Introduction, Syntactic Processing, Semantic Analysis, Discourse and
Pragmatic Processing, Statistical Natural Language Processing, Spell Checking, Expert Systems,
Representing and Using Domain Knowledge, Expert System Shells, Explanation, Knowledge Acquisition.

textbooks: 1. E. Rich, K. Knight, and S. B. Nair, “Artificial Intelligence”, 3rd Edition, McGraw-Hill, 2009.
2. S. Russell and P. Norvig, “Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach”, 4th Edition, Pearson,
references: 1. D. W. Patterson, “Introduction to Artificial Intelligence and Expert Systems”, 1st Edition, PHI,
2. G. F. Luger, “Artificial Intelligence: Structures and Strategies for Complex Problem Solving”, 6th
laboratory: 1. Write a program to implement breadth-first search.
2. Write a program to implement depth-first search.
3. Write a program to implement best-first search.
4. Write a program to implement A* algorithm.
5. Write a program to implement AO* algorithm.
6. Write a program to implement minimax algorithm.
7. Write a program to implement alpha-beta pruning.
8. Write a program to implement a simple expert system.
9. Write a program to implement a simple neural network.
10. Write a program to implement a simple genetic algorithm.

content.name: Artificial Intelligence and Lab
content.prerequisites: Basic Programming, Data Structures CIE Marks 50

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of object-oriented modeling and design.
CO2: Apply the concepts of UML and its diagrams.
CO3: Apply the concepts of structural and behavioral modeling.
CO4: Understand the concepts of architectural modeling.
CO5: Understand the concepts of design patterns.
“Object-Oriented Analysis and Design with Applications”, 3rd Edition, Addison-Wesley, 2007.
Design and Iterative Development”, 3rd Edition, Pearson, 2005.

sections.title: Second Semester Syllabus
content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of machine learning.
CO2: Apply the concepts of supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning.
CO3: Apply the concepts of regression, classification, clustering, and dimensionality reduction.
CO4: Understand the concepts of neural networks and deep learning.
CO5: Understand the concepts of natural language processing and computer vision.

objectives: 1. To understand the basic concepts of machine learning.
2. To learn the concepts of supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning.
3. To understand the concepts of regression, classification, clustering, and dimensionality reduction.
4. To learn the concepts of neural networks and deep learning.
5. To understand the concepts of natural language processing and computer vision.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: INTRODUCTION TO MACHINE LEARNING
9 Hours
What is Machine Learning, Types of Machine Learning, Supervised Learning, Unsupervised Learning,
Reinforcement Learning, The Machine Learning Process, A First Application: The Iris Dataset.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: SUPERVISED LEARNING
9 Hours
Regression, Linear Regression, Multiple Linear Regression, Polynomial Regression, Support Vector
Regression, Decision Tree Regression, Random Forest Regression, Classification, Logistic Regression,
K-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector Machine, Naive Bayes, Decision Tree Classification, Random
Forest Classification.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: UNSUPERVISED LEARNING
9 Hours
Clustering, K-Means Clustering, Hierarchical Clustering, Density-Based Clustering, Dimensionality
Reduction, Principal Component Analysis, Linear Discriminant Analysis, Kernel PCA.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: NEURAL NETWORKS AND DEEP LEARNING
9 Hours
Introduction to Neural Networks, The Perceptron, Multilayer Perceptrons, Backpropagation, Activation
Functions, Loss Functions, Optimizers, Introduction to Deep Learning, Convolutional Neural Networks,
Recurrent Neural Networks, Long Short-Term Memory, Autoencoders.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: NATURAL LANGUAGE PROCESSING AND COMPUTER VISION
9 Hours
Natural Language Processing, Bag-of-Words, TF-IDF, Word2Vec, GloVe, Computer Vision, Image
Classification, Object Detection, Image Segmentation, Transfer Learning.

textbooks: 1. A. Géron, “Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn, Keras & TensorFlow”, 2nd Edition,
2. S. Raschka and V. Mirjalili, “Python Machine Learning”, 3rd Edition, Packt Publishing, 2019.
references: 1. T. M. Mitchell, “Machine Learning”, 1st Edition, McGraw-Hill, 1997.
2. C. M. Bishop, “Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning”, 1st Edition, Springer, 2006.
laboratory: 1. Write a Python program to implement linear regression.
2. Write a Python program to implement logistic regression.
3. Write a Python program to implement k-nearest neighbors.
4. Write a Python program to implement support vector machine.
5. Write a Python program to implement naive Bayes.
6. Write a Python program to implement decision tree.
7. Write a Python program to implement random forest.
8. Write a Python program to implement k-means clustering.
9. Write a Python program to implement principal component analysis.
10. Write a Python program to implement a simple neural network.

content.name: Machine Learning using Python and Lab
content.prerequisites: Basic Programming, Python Programming CIE Marks 50

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of advanced Java programming.
CO2: Apply the concepts of multithreading, networking, and database programming.
CO3: Apply the concepts of web programming using servlets and JSPs.
CO4: Understand the concepts of web services and enterprise Java beans.
CO5: Understand the concepts of Spring and Hibernate frameworks.

objectives: 1. To understand the basic concepts of advanced Java programming.
2. To learn the concepts of multithreading, networking, and database programming.
3. To understand the concepts of web programming using servlets and JSPs.
4. To learn the concepts of web services and enterprise Java beans.
5. To understand the concepts of Spring and Hibernate frameworks.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: MULTITHREADING AND NETWORKING
9 Hours
Multithreading, The Java Thread Model, The Main Thread, Creating a Thread, Creating Multiple
Threads, Using isAlive() and join(), Thread Priorities, Synchronization, Interthread Communication,
Suspending, Resuming, and Stopping Threads, Networking, Networking Basics, The Networking Classes
and Interfaces, InetAddress, TCP/IP Client Sockets, URL, URLConnection, TCP/IP Server Sockets,
Datagrams.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: DATABASE PROGRAMMING
9 Hours
JDBC, The JDBC Architecture, The JDBC API, The Steps to Create a JDBC Application, The
DriverManager Class, The Connection Interface, The Statement Interface, The PreparedStatement
Interface, The CallableStatement Interface, The ResultSet Interface, The ResultSetMetaData Interface,
RowSet, Transactions, Connection Pooling.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: WEB PROGRAMMING
9 Hours
Servlets, The Servlet Lifecycle, The Servlet API, The javax.servlet Package, The javax.servlet.http
Package, Handling HTTP Requests and Responses, Using Cookies, Session Tracking, JavaServer Pages
(JSP), The JSP Lifecycle, The JSP API, JSP Implicit Objects, JSP Directives, JSP Scripting Elements,
JSP Actions, Expression Language (EL), JavaServer Pages Standard Tag Library (JSTL).

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: WEB SERVICES AND ENTERPRISE JAVA BEANS
9 Hours
Web Services, Introduction to Web Services, SOAP, WSDL, UDDI, JAX-WS, JAX-RS, Enterprise
JavaBeans (EJB), The EJB Architecture, The EJB Components, Session Beans, Message-Driven Beans,
Entity Beans, The EJB Lifecycle, The EJB Security, The EJB Transactions.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: SPRING AND HIBERNATE
9 Hours
Spring, Introduction to Spring, The Spring Architecture, The Spring Modules, Inversion of Control (IoC)
and Dependency Injection (DI), Aspect-Oriented Programming (AOP), Spring MVC, Spring JDBC,
Spring ORM, Hibernate, Introduction to Hibernate, The Hibernate Architecture, The Hibernate
Configuration, The Hibernate Sessions, The Hibernate Objects, The Hibernate Query Language (HQL),
The Hibernate Criteria API.
STE 2023-25 School of Science Studies
Master of Computer Applications

textbooks: 1. H. Schildt, “Java: The Complete Reference”, 11th Edition, McGraw-Hill, 2019.
2. C. S. Horstmann, “Core Java, Volume II—Advanced Features”, 11th Edition, Prentice Hall,
references: 1. C. Bauer, G. King, and G. Gregory, “Java Persistence with Hibernate”, 2nd Edition, Manning
2. C. Walls, “Spring in Action”, 5th Edition, Manning Publications, 2018.
laboratory: 1. Write a Java program to implement multithreading.
2. Write a Java program to implement networking.
3. Write a Java program to implement database programming using JDBC.
4. Write a Java program to implement a servlet.
5. Write a Java program to implement a JSP.
6. Write a Java program to implement a web service.
7. Write a Java program to implement an EJB.
8. Write a Java program to implement Spring framework.
9. Write a Java program to implement Hibernate framework.
10. Write a Java program to develop a web application using Spring and Hibernate.

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of distributed and parallel computing.
CO2: Apply the concepts of communication, coordination, and synchronization in distributed systems.
CO3: Apply the concepts of distributed algorithms, transactions, and replication.
CO4: Understand the concepts of parallel programming models and algorithms.
CO5: Understand the concepts of parallel architectures and programming.
Networked Workstations and Parallel Computers”, 2nd Edition, Pearson, 2005.

objectives: 1. To understand the basic concepts of distributed and parallel computing.
2. To learn the concepts of communication, coordination, and synchronization in distributed systems.
3. To understand the concepts of distributed algorithms, transactions, and replication.
4. To learn the concepts of parallel programming models and algorithms.
5. To understand the concepts of parallel architectures and programming.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: INTRODUCTION TO DISTRIBUTED AND PARALLEL COMPUTING
9 Hours
Introduction to Distributed Systems, Characterization of Distributed Systems, System Models,
Architectural Models, Fundamental Models, Introduction to Parallel Computing, Parallel Programming
Platforms, Principles of Parallel Algorithm Design.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: COMMUNICATION, COORDINATION, AND SYNCHRONIZATION
9 Hours
Interprocess Communication, The API for the Internet Protocols, External Data Representation and
Marshalling, Client-Server Communication, Group Communication, Case Study: Interprocess
Communication in UNIX, Coordination, Clock Synchronization, Logical Clocks, Mutual Exclusion,
Election Algorithms.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: DISTRIBUTED ALGORITHMS, TRANSACTIONS, AND REPLICATION
9 Hours
Distributed Algorithms, Distributed Deadlock, Distributed Shared Memory, Distributed File Systems,
Transactions, Nested Transactions, Locks, Optimistic Concurrency Control, Timestamp Ordering,
Comparison of Methods for Concurrency Control, Replication, System Model and Group
Communication, Fault-Tolerant Services, Case Studies: The Andrew File System, The Sun Network
File System.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: PARALLEL PROGRAMMING MODELS AND ALGORITHMS
9 Hours
Parallel Programming Models, Shared Memory Model, Threads Model, Message Passing Model, Data
Parallel Model, Other Models, Parallel Algorithms, Sorting, Searching, Matrix Multiplication, Graph
Algorithms.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: PARALLEL ARCHITECTURES AND PROGRAMMING
9 Hours
Parallel Architectures, Multiprocessors, Multicomputers, Clusters, Grids, Clouds, Parallel
Programming, Shared-Memory Programming with OpenMP, Message-Passing Programming with MPI,
Data Parallel Programming with CUDA.

2. A. Grama, A. Gupta, G. Karypis, and V. Kumar, “Introduction to Parallel Computing”, 2nd

2. B. Wilkinson and M. Allen, “Parallel Programming: Techniques and Applications Using

content.name: Distributed and Parallel Computing
content.prerequisites: Operating Systems, Computer Networks CIE Marks 50

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of advanced computer networks.
CO2: Apply the concepts of wireless and mobile networks.
CO3: Apply the concepts of multimedia networking and quality of service.
CO4: Understand the concepts of network security and management.
CO5: Understand the concepts of software defined networking and network functions virtualization.

objectives: 1. To understand the basic concepts of advanced computer networks.
2. To learn the concepts of wireless and mobile networks.
3. To understand the concepts of multimedia networking and quality of service.
4. To learn the concepts of network security and management.
5. To understand the concepts of software defined networking and network functions virtualization.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: WIRELESS AND MOBILE NETWORKS
9 Hours
Introduction, Wireless Links and Network Characteristics, WiFi: 802.11 Wireless LANs, Cellular
Internet Access, Mobility Management: Principles, Mobile IP, Managing Mobility in Cellular Networks,
Wireless and Mobility: Impact on Higher-Layer Protocols.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: MULTIMEDIA NETWORKING
9 Hours
Multimedia Networking Applications, Streaming Stored Video, Voice-over-IP, Protocols for Real-Time
Conversational Applications, Network Support for Multimedia, Quality of Service, Scheduling and
Policing Mechanisms, Integrated Services, Differentiated Services.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: NETWORK SECURITY
9 Hours
Principles of Cryptography, Message Integrity and End-Point Authentication, Securing E-mail,
Securing TCP Connections: SSL, Network-Layer Security: IPsec, Securing Wireless LANs, Operational
Security: Firewalls and Intrusion Detection Systems.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: NETWORK MANAGEMENT
9 Hours
What is Network Management?, The Infrastructure for Network Management, The Internet-Standard
Management Framework, ASN.1, SNMP, Security and Administration, TMN, Network Management
Tools and Systems.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: SOFTWARE DEFINED NETWORKING AND NETWORK FUNCTIONS
9 Hours
VIRTUALIZATION
Introduction to Software Defined Networking (SDN), The SDN Architecture, The SDN Control Plane,
The SDN Data Plane, The SDN Application Plane, Network Functions Virtualization (NFV), The NFV
Architecture, The NFV Infrastructure, The NFV Management and Orchestration.

textbooks: 1. J. F. Kurose and K. W. Ross, “Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach”, 8th Edition,
2. W. Stallings, “Data and Computer Communications”, 10th Edition, Pearson, 2014.
references: 1. L. L. Peterson and B. S. Davie, “Computer Networks: A Systems Approach”, 5th Edition,
2. A. S. Tanenbaum and D. J. Wetherall, “Computer Networks”, 5th Edition, Pearson, 2011.

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of optimization.
CO2: Apply the concepts of linear programming, transportation, and assignment problems.
CO3: Apply the concepts of integer programming, dynamic programming, and game theory.
CO4: Understand the concepts of queuing theory and simulation.
CO5: Understand the concepts of project management and network analysis.

objectives: 1. To understand the basic concepts of optimization.
2. To learn the concepts of linear programming, transportation, and assignment problems.
3. To understand the concepts of integer programming, dynamic programming, and game theory.
4. To learn the concepts of queuing theory and simulation.
5. To understand the concepts of project management and network analysis.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: INTRODUCTION TO OPTIMIZATION
9 Hours
Introduction, Historical Development, Engineering Applications of Optimization, Statement of an
Optimization Problem, Classification of Optimization Problems, Optimization Techniques.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: LINEAR PROGRAMMING
9 Hours
Introduction, Formulation of Linear Programming Problems, Graphical Solution, Simplex Method,
Big-M Method, Two-Phase Method, Duality in Linear Programming, Sensitivity Analysis.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: TRANSPORTATION AND ASSIGNMENT PROBLEMS
9 Hours
Introduction, Formulation of Transportation Problem, North-West Corner Method, Least-Cost Method,
Vogel’s Approximation Method, Optimality Test, MODI Method, Unbalanced Transportation Problem,
Degeneracy in Transportation Problem, Assignment Problem, Hungarian Method, Unbalanced
Assignment Problem, Traveling Salesman Problem.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: INTEGER PROGRAMMING, DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING, AND GAME THEORY
9 Hours
Introduction, Integer Programming, Gomory’s Cutting Plane Method, Branch and Bound Method,
Dynamic Programming, Bellman’s Principle of Optimality, Game Theory, Two-Person Zero-Sum
Games, Minimax-Maximin Principle, Saddle Point, Games with Mixed Strategies, Dominance Property,
Graphical Method, LPP Method.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: QUEUING THEORY AND SIMULATION
9 Hours
Introduction, Queuing Models, M/M/1 Model, M/M/c Model, M/G/1 Model, Simulation,
Monte-Carlo Simulation, Simulation of Queuing Systems.

textbooks: 1. S. S. Rao, “Engineering Optimization: Theory and Practice”, 5th Edition, Wiley, 2019.
2. H. A. Taha, “Operations Research: An Introduction”, 10th Edition, Pearson, 2017.
references: 1. F. S. Hillier and G. J. Lieberman, “Introduction to Operations Research”, 11th Edition,
2. K. Deb, “Optimization for Engineering Design: Algorithms and Examples”, 2nd Edition, PHI,

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of data warehousing and data mining.
CO2: Apply the concepts of data preprocessing, data warehouse and OLAP technology.
CO3: Apply the concepts of data mining primitives, languages, and system architectures.
CO4: Understand the concepts of association rule mining, classification, and prediction.
CO5: Understand the concepts of cluster analysis and outlier detection.
Tools and Techniques”, 4th Edition, Morgan Kaufmann, 2016.

objectives: 1. To understand the basic concepts of data warehousing and data mining.
2. To learn the concepts of data preprocessing, data warehouse and OLAP technology.
3. To understand the concepts of data mining primitives, languages, and system architectures.
4. To learn the concepts of association rule mining, classification, and prediction.
5. To understand the concepts of cluster analysis and outlier detection.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT I: INTRODUCTION TO DATA WAREHOUSING AND DATA MINING
9 Hours
What is a Data Warehouse?, A Multidimensional Data Model, Data Warehouse Architecture, Data
Warehouse Implementation, From Data Warehousing to Data Mining, What is Data Mining?, Kinds of
Data, Kinds of Patterns, Technologies Used, Kinds of Applications Targeted, Major Issues in Data
Mining.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT II: DATA PREPROCESSING, DATA WAREHOUSE AND OLAP TECHNOLOGY
9 Hours
Data Preprocessing, Data Cleaning, Data Integration, Data Reduction, Data Transformation and Data
Discretization, Data Warehouse and OLAP Technology, An Overview, A Multidimensional Data Model,
Data Warehouse Architecture, Data Warehouse Implementation, From Data Warehousing to Data Mining.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT III: DATA MINING PRIMITIVES, LANGUAGES, AND SYSTEM ARCHITECTURES
9 Hours
Data Mining Primitives, Data Mining Query Language, Designing Graphical User Interfaces Based on a
Data Mining Query Language, Architectures of Data Mining Systems.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT IV: ASSOCIATION RULE MINING, CLASSIFICATION, AND PREDICTION
9 Hours
Association Rule Mining, Mining Single-Dimensional Boolean Association Rules from Transactional
Databases, Mining Multilevel Association Rules from Transactional Databases, Mining Multidimensional
Association Rules from Relational Databases and Data Warehouses, From Association Mining to
Correlation Analysis, Constraint-Based Association Mining, Classification and Prediction, Issues
Regarding Classification and Prediction, Classification by Decision Tree Induction, Bayesian
Classification, Rule-Based Classification, Classification by Backpropagation, Support Vector Machines,
Associative Classification, Lazy Learners, Other Classification Methods, Prediction, Accuracy and Error
Measures, Evaluating the Accuracy of a Classifier or Predictor, Ensemble Methods.

other_content.title: Other Content
description: UNIT V: CLUSTER ANALYSIS AND OUTLIER DETECTION
9 Hours
Cluster Analysis, Types of Data in Cluster Analysis, A Categorization of Major Clustering Methods,
Partitioning Methods, Hierarchical Methods, Density-Based Methods, Grid-Based Methods, Model-
Based Clustering Methods, Clustering High-Dimensional Data, Constraint-Based Cluster Analysis,
Outlier Detection, Outlier Detection Methods, Statistical Approaches, Proximity-Based Approaches,
Clustering-Based Approaches, Classification-Based Approaches.
STE 2023-25 School of Science Studies
Master of Computer Applications

textbooks: 1. J. Han, M. Kamber, and J. Pei, “Data Mining: Concepts and Techniques”, 3rd Edition, Morgan
2. P. N. Tan, M. Steinbach, and V. Kumar, “Introduction to Data Mining”, 2nd Edition, Pearson,
references: 1. I. H. Witten, E. Frank, M. A. Hall, and C. J. Pal, “Data Mining: Practical Machine Learning
2. G. K. Gupta, “Introduction to Data Mining with Case Studies”, 3rd Edition, PHI, 2014.
laboratory: 1. Write a program to implement data preprocessing.
2. Write a program to implement a data warehouse.
3. Write a program to implement OLAP operations.
4. Write a program to implement Apriori algorithm.
5. Write a program to implement FP-growth algorithm.
6. Write a program to implement decision tree algorithm.
7. Write a program to implement Naive Bayes algorithm.
8. Write a program to implement k-means clustering algorithm.
9. Write a program to implement k-medoids clustering algorithm.
10. Write a program to implement outlier detection.

content.name: Data Warehousing & Data Mining and Lab

content: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
CO1: Understand the basic concepts of mobile application development.
CO2: Apply the concepts of Android and iOS platforms.
CO3: Apply the concepts of UI design, data storage, and networking.
CO4: Understand the concepts of location-based services, sensors, and multimedia.
CO5: Understand the concepts of publishing and distributing mobile applications.
